description: A broad range of percussive electronic music genres made largely for nightclubs, raves, and festivals. It is generally produced for playback by DJs who create seamless selections of tracks, called a DJ mix, by segueing from one recording to another.

subgenres.name: House
subgenres.description: Originated in Chicago in the early 1980s. It is characterized by a 4/4 time signature, a tempo between 120 and 130 beats per minute (BPM), and a prominent kick drum on every beat.

subgenres.name: Techno
subgenres.description: Emerged from Detroit in the mid-to-late 1980s. It is characterized by a repetitive 4/4 rhythm, use of synthesizers, and a focus on rhythmic and textural exploration over melodic development.

subgenres.name: Trance
subgenres.description: Developed in the 1990s in Germany. It is characterized by a tempo between 125 and 150 BPM, repeating melodic phrases, and a musical form that builds tension and release.

subgenres.name: Dubstep
subgenres.description: Originated in South London in the early 2000s. It is generally characterized by sparse, syncopated drum patterns with prominent sub-bass frequencies and a focus on 'bass drops'.

subgenres.name: Drum & Bass (D&B)
subgenres.description: Emerged in England in the early 1990s. The genre is characterized by fast breakbeats (typically 165–185 BPM) with heavy bass and sub-bass lines.

subgenres.name: Hyperpop
subgenres.description: A loosely defined music movement and microgenre characterized by a maximalist or exaggerated approach to pop music. Artists often integrate pop and avant-garde sensibilities, drawing on elements of electronic, hip hop, and dance music.
